German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German al-ein. Cognate with Middle English al-one, English alone, Low German alleene (Münsterländisch), alläine (Sauerländisch).[1]

Alternative forms[edit]

  • alleine (chiefly colloquial, only occasionally in formal writing)

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /aˈlaɪn/
  • audio (Austria)
    		(file)
  • Audio
    		(file)
  • Rhymes: -aɪ̯n

Adjective[edit]

allein (not comparable)

  1. (only predicative) alone
    Er ist ganz allein.
    He is all alone.

Declension[edit]

Declension of allein

predicativeer ist alleinsie ist alleines ist alleinsie sind allein
strong declension
(without article)		nominative————

weak declension
(with definite article)		nominative————
genitive————
dative————
accusative————
mixed declension
(with indefinite article)		nominative————
genitive————
dative————
accusative————

Adverb[edit]

allein

  1. alone
    Er schrieb das Buch allein.
    He wrote the book alone.
    Allein im Jahr 2012 starben 500 Menschen an der Krankheit.
    In 2012 alone, 500 people died from the illness.
  2. (formal, literary) only
    Allein ein Wunder kann uns noch helfen.
    Only a miracle can help us now.

Synonyms[edit]

  • nur, bloß
  • ausschließlich

Derived terms[edit]

  • alleinerziehend

See also[edit]

  • einsam
